facts.text: G. A. Chambers was carrying on two businesses, one in the name and style of Chambers Co. and the other in the name and style of Chrome Leather Company.

anchor.surface_text: One G. A. Chambers was carrying on two businesses, one in the name and style of Chambers Co. and the other in the name and style of Chrome Leather Company.

facts.text: Chambers Co. was concerned with export of hides, skins and mica, insurance and shipping brokerage.

anchor.surface_text: The first business was companycerned with export of hides, skins and mica, insurance and shipping brokerage.

facts.text: The said Chambers Co. was an assessee under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1918.

anchor.surface_text: The said Chambers Co. was an assessee under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1918.

facts.text: In or about 1931 G. A. Chambers handed over the management of the said business to his son, K. H. Chambers.

anchor.surface_text: As the business was in a bad way, in or about 1931 G. A. Chambers handed over the management of the said business to his son, K. H. Chambers.

facts.text: Appellant's case is that towards the end of 1932 G. A. Chambers transferred the business to his son K. H. Chambers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case is that towards the end of 1932 G. A. Chambers transferred the business to his son, K. Chambers, and that after the said transfer,

facts.text: K. H. Chambers carried on the business in his own name till January 1, 1948, when the business was taken over by a limited company.

anchor.surface_text: K. Chambers, and that after the said transfer, K. H. Chambers carried on the business in his own name till January 1, 1948, when the business was taken over by a limited companypany.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1948-49 K. H. Chambers claimed relief under s. 25(4) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1948-49 K. H. Chambers claimed relief under s. 25  4  of the Act on the ground that the business had been assessed

facts.text: Income-tax Officer by order dated March 18, 1949 held that K. H. Chambers did not take over the business of his father as a whole concern.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, by his order, dated March 18, 1949, held that K. H. Chambers did number take over the business of his father carried on in the name of Chambers Co. as a whole running companycern

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: and, therefore, the assessee was number entitled to relief under s. 25  4  of the Act. On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income- tax OfficeR

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the business carried on by K.H. Chambers was not the same business assessed under 1918 Act.

anchor.surface_text: and held that the business carried on by K.H. Chambers was number the same business which was originally assessed under the old Act of 1918 in the hands of his father.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court under s. 66(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal came to the same companyclusion and found that the identity of the business carried on by the father was lost in the hands of the son,

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative in favour of the assessee holding succession after November 1932.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Madras for its opinion under s. 66 t  of the Act Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in law in refusing relief under Section 25 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act to the assessee.

facts.text: In 1932, G. A. Chambers handed over the sole management of Chambers Co. to K. H. Chambers.

anchor.surface_text: G. A. Chambers, the father, was carrying on two independent businesses, one in the export of hides, skins and mica, in insurance and shipping brokerage under the name and style of Chambers Co. and the other under the name and style of Chrome Leather Company. In 1932, G. A. Chambers handed over the sole management of the former business to his son, K. H. Chambers.

facts.text: On July 7, 1932, G. A. Chambers wrote a letter to K. H. Chambers.

anchor.surface_text: In July 1932, the son was going to foreign companyntries, presumably in companynection with his business. On July 7, 1932, before the son left India, G. A. Chambers wrote a letter to him informing him that by the end of August 1932 the sum of Rs. 40,000 invested by him in the business would run out,

facts.text: On July 8, 1932, the son replied to the father.

anchor.surface_text: On July 8, 1932, the son replied to the father to the effect that he would prefer to start right afresh in his own name or in the name of Chambers Co.

facts.text: On December 5, 1932, G.A. Chambers asked auditors to close accounts of Chambers Co. upto November 30, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: On December 5, 1932, G.A. Chambers asked his auditors, M s. Fraser Ross, to close the accounts of Chambers Co. and send the balance-sheet, venture and profit and loss accounts for 8 months ending November 30, 1932,

facts.text: From December 1, 1932, K. H. Chambers ran the export business separately in his own name.

anchor.surface_text: This letter shows that from December 1, 1932, K. Chambers would run the export business and that the accounts, of G. A. Chambers in the Chambers Co. would be transferred to the accounts of Chrome Leather Co.

facts.text: Auditors prepared balance-sheet showing G.A. Chambers assets Rs. 5,67,485-10-2 and liabilities Rs. 5,95,433-12-3; K.H. Chambers assets Rs. 55,214-2-3 and liabilities Rs. 27,266-0-2.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the instructions given by G. A. Chambers, M s. Fraser Ross, the auditors, prepared a balance-sheet of the Chambers Co. and also the individual accounts of G. A. Chambers and K. H. Chambers. The balance-sheet shows that A. Chambers was given assets valued at Rs. 5,67,485- 10-2 and liabilities valued at Rs. 5,95,433-12-3K. H. Chambers was given assets valued at Rs. 55,214-2-3 and liabilities valued at Rs. 27,266-0-2.

facts.text: Father took over liabilities and assets including buildings and machinery; son given stock in trade and small amount of debts.

anchor.surface_text: The liabilities given toK. H. Chambers includes the amount representing the difference between the value of the assets and liabilities given to G. A. Chambers. Broadly stated, the father had taken over the liabilities of the Company and assets, including buildings and machinery sufficient to discharge the liabilities, while the son was given the stock in trade and a small amount of debts.

facts.text: K. H. Chambers continued to operate the same lines of business, using same premises, telephone number, Post Box No., stationery, trade marks and important sections of staff.

anchor.surface_text: After this allotment, it is companyceded that K. H. Chambers companytinued to operate the same lines of business as was carried on by Chambers Co. taking over all the companystituents of that business, using the same premises, the same telephone number, Post Box No., private companyes and trade marks and the important sections of the staff that belonged to Chamber Co.

facts.text: On May 23, 1933, G. A. Chambers wrote to Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company transferring agency to K. H. Chambers.

anchor.surface_text: On May 23, 1933. G. A. Chambers wrote to the Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company, Calcutta, wherein he stated We companyfirm our companyversation with your representative that inasmuch as we have transferred all our export business to Mr. K. H. Chambers,

facts.text: Department concedes G. A. Chambers utilized good offices to transfer insurance agency to K. H. Chambers.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companyceded by the Department that G. A. Chambers utilized his good offices in getting the Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company to transfer the agency of that companypany to Chambers Co. run by K. H. Chambers.

facts.text: Court held there was succession to the business within meaning of s. 25(4).

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that on the facts found or admitted there is a clear case of succession in the present case.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment, dated December 21, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 136 of 1956.
This appeal by special leave raises the question of the applicability of s. 25 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act, hereinafter called the Act, to the assessment in question.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Karkhanis, learned counsel for the Revenue, raised before us two contentions, namely,  i  the question referred by the Tribunal to the High Court was only a pure question of fact and, therefore, the High Court has no jurisdiction to give its opinion thereon and  ii  where the transferor retains the goodwill and most of the assets

issues.text: where the transferor retains the goodwill and most of the assets and the transferee carries on the same business with a part of the assets of the principal business, it cannot be said that there is succession to the whole of the business within the meaning of s. 25(4) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: and  ii  where the transferor retains the goodwill and most of the assets and the transferee carries on the same business with a part of the assets of the principal business, it cannot be said that there is succession to the whole of the business within the meaning of s. 25  4  of the Act. We shall take the second question first.

arguments.claim: Succession requires change of ownership, transfer of whole business, substantial identity and continuity

anchor.surface_text: Succession involves change of ownership that is, the transferor goes out and the transferee comes in it connotes that the whole business is transferred it also implies that substantially the identity and the continuity of the business are preserved.

arguments.claim: Arrangement where transferor retains assets/liabilities to enable transferee run business unhampered does not detract from succession

anchor.surface_text: If there is a transfer of a business, any arrangement between the transferor and the transferee in respect of some of the assets and liabilities not with a view to enable the transferor to run a part of the business transferred but to enable the transferee to run the business unhampered by the load of debts

arguments.claim: Finding of succession under s.25(4) is mixed question of law and fact involving application of legal tests

anchor.surface_text: The tests crystallized by decisions have given a legal content to the expression succession within the meaning of S. 25 4  of the Act and whether facts proved satisfy those tests is a mixed question of law and fact.

arguments.claim: Retention of assets by father only to discharge debts and facilitate son's business, not to continue own business

anchor.surface_text: The taking over of the assets and liabilities by the father was not for the purpose of continuing to do a business of his own in the same lines, but to facilitate the carrying on of the transferred business by the son effectively and profitably.

holdings.text: on the facts found or admitted there is a clear case of succession in the present case

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that on the facts found or admitted there is a clear case of succession in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show change of ownership from father to son, transfer of business as going concern with stock, debts, premises, staff, telephone, Post Box, stationery, trademarks; continuity in same lines of export, insurance, brokerage; father retained assets/liabilities only to discharge debts and facilitate son's unhampered operation, not to continue own business; satisfies tests from precedents

holdings.text: Succession involves change of ownership that is, the transferor goes out and the transferee comes in it connotes that the whole business is transferred it also implies that substantially the identity and the continuity of the business are preserved

anchor.surface_text: Succession involves change of ownership that is, the transferor goes out and the transferee comes in it connotes that the whole business is transferred it also implies that substantially the identity and the continuity of the business are preserved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesizes tests from Simons Income Tax, Reynolds v Ogston, Rangoon HC cases (N.N. Firm, A.L.V.R.P. Firm), Patna HC (Jittanram), Malayalam Plantations: change of ownership, whole business (substantial identity even if minor assets omitted), continuity, similar trade, goodwill/staff/stock/debts treatment, no interval

holdings.text: If there is a transfer of a business, any arrangement between the transferor and the transferee in respect of some of the assets and liabilities not with a view to enable the transferor to run a part of the business transferred but to enable the transferee to run the business unhampered by the load of debts or for any other appropriate collateral purpose cannot detract from the totality of succession

anchor.surface_text: If there is a transfer of a business, any arrangement between the transferor and the transferee in respect of some of the assets and liabilities not with a view to enable the transferor to run a part of the business transferred but to enable the transferee to run the business unhampered by the load of debts or for any other appropriate collateral purpose cannot detract from the totality of succession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes retention for debt discharge/facilitation (as here, father took liabilities/assets to unburden son) from retention to run competing/partial business; cites Malayalam Plantations (going concern despite no book debts/selling org); applies purposively to preserve succession where identity/continuity intact

holdings.text: The tests crystallized by decisions have given a legal content to the expression succession within the meaning of S. 25(4) of the Act and whether facts proved satisfy those tests is a mixed question of law and fact

anchor.surface_text: The tests crystallized by decisions have given a legal content to the expression succession within the meaning of S. 25 4  of the Act and whether facts proved satisfy those tests is a mixed question of law and fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies SC precedent (Meenakshi Mills: inference from facts via legal principle is mixed q of law/fact); distinguishes pure fact (unreviewable unless perverse/no evidence) from application of crystallized legal tests (change/ownership/integrity/identity/continuity); English cases (Bell v National Provincial, Wilson v Chibbett, Malayalam) confirm reviewable if wrong legal tests applied

holdings.text: a question of law arose out of the Tribunals order and the High Court has jurisdiction to ascertain the correctness of the finding given by the Tribunal on the question of succession

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that a question of law arose out of the Tribunals order and the High Court has jurisdiction to ascertain the correctness of the finding given by the Tribunal on the question of succession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from h4: since mixed question and Tribunal finding unsatisfied legal tests (ignored continuity despite retention purpose, perversion), reference under s.66(1) proper; High Court correctly reviewed and reversed

precedents.citation: Briton Ferry Steel Co., Ltd. v. Barry, 1940 1 B. 463, 476

anchor.surface_text: Briton Ferry Steel Co., Ltd. v. Barry, 1940 1 B. 463, 476 . In Reynolds, Sons Co., Ltd. v. Ogston  H. M. Inspector of Taxes   1 , Lord Hanworth

precedents.case_name: Briton Ferry Steel Co Ltd v Barry
precedents.cited_proposition: one of the cases from which tests for succession have been derived, including whether there was an interval in carrying on the trade

precedents.citation: Reynolds, Sons Co., Ltd. v. Ogston H. M. Inspector of Taxes

anchor.surface_text: Reynolds, Sons Co., Ltd. v. Ogston H. M. Inspector of Taxes   1 , Lord Hanworth, M. R., accepted the following tests laid down by Rowlatt, J., to ascertain whether there was a succession

precedents.case_name: Reynolds Sons & Co Ltd v Ogston
precedents.cited_proposition: tests to ascertain whether there was a succession require a very close identity between the business of the former proprietorship and the business in the present proprietorship
precedents.cited_holding: You want to measure the income of the successor by the past history of the business, it is therefore essential that there should be a very close identity between the business of the former proprietorship and the business in the present proprietorship.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma N. N. Firm

anchor.surface_text: The Rangoon High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma N. N. Firm  2  had to companysider the meaning of the word succeeded in S. 26 2  of the Income-tax Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: a person succeeds another in carrying on a business only if he succeeds to the business as a whole
precedents.cited_holding: In order that a person should be held to have succeeded another person in carrying on a business, profession or vocation, it is necessary that the person succeeding should have succeeded his predecessor in carrying on the business as a whole.

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income- tax, Burma v. A. L. V. R. P. Firm

anchor.surface_text: The Rangoon High Court again in The Commissioner of Income- tax, Burma v. A. L. V. R. P. Firm  3  reiterated the same principle.

precedents.cited_proposition: reiterated that succession requires succeeding to the business as a whole

precedents.citation: Jittanram Nirmalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Patna High Court in Jittanram Nirmalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa,  4   after companysidering the relevant decisions

precedents.case_name: Jittanram Nirmalram v CIT Bihar and Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: sufficient if there is substantial identity or similarity in the nature and extent of activities between transferor and transferee; not necessary to take over mathematically same extent or all businesses
precedents.cited_holding: For the application of Section 26 2 or Section 25 4 it is number essential in every case that the successor firm should have mathematically the same extent of business as the predecessor firm or that it should have taken over the same extent of trade or the same line or set of customers as belonging to the predecessor firm number does it mean that the successor firm should have taken over all the different businesses which the predecessor firm had carried on.

precedents.citation: Malayalam Plantations, Ltd. v. Clark H. Inspector of Taxes

anchor.surface_text: In Malayalam Plantations, Ltd. v. Clark  H. Inspector of Taxes  1  the appellant- companypany therein, by an agreement dated March 28, 1928, acquired

precedents.cited_proposition: taking over business as going concern constitutes succession even if some assets not required for carrying on business not transferred
precedents.cited_holding: The substance of what was done, I think, clearly was this The thing was taken over as a going companycern, taken over with the things growing on it, and with the companylies employed to work the estate.

precedents.citation: Meenakshi Mills, Madurai v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Meenakshi Mills, Madurai v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1  laid down the following propositions which are relevant to the question number raised before us

precedents.case_name: Meenakshi Mills Madurai v CIT Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: inference from facts found applying principle of law is mixed question of law and fact open to review; pure question of fact only if no evidence or perverse
precedents.cited_holding: Where an ultimate finding on an issue is an inference to be drawn from the facts found, on the application of any principle of law, there is a mixed question of law and fact, and the inference from the facts found is, in such a case, a question of law and is open to review by the Court. Where the final determination of the issue does number involve an application of any principle of law, an inference from the facts is a pure inference of fact although it is drawn from other basic facts.

precedents.cited_holding: No succession say the Commissioners within the meaning of the said 4th Rule. That is the proposition of law we have to decide as distinguished from fact, and we are entitled to differ from that view.

anchor.surface_text: If there is a transfer of a business, any arrangement between the transferor and the transferee in respect of some of the assets and liabilities not with a view to enable the transferor to run a part of the business transferred but to enable the transferee to run the business unhampered by the load of debts or for any other appropriate collateral purpose cannot detract from the totality of succession.
